messages: 69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:25): maybe instead of "high quality" and "low quality" as conformance levels, we should have "high priority" and "low piority" errors
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:25): where high priority = things that really cause a lot of problems and should definitely be fixed
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:26): and low priority = things that cause problems, but not disasters
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:26): so for example a missing </style> is a high priority error since it hides the whole rest of the page
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:26): wouldn't most content model violation bugs then be low priority?
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:27): but a style="" attribute in a production page is a low priority error since it just means that you can't easily add an alternative style sheet
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:28): now there's a marginally good argument against using style="" (though it applies equally to <style scoped> and even <style>, no?)
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:28): <style> can have a title=""
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:28): (without one it's a "persistent style sheet")
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:29): (but it's easy to migrate from one persistent style sheet to a set of alternatives just by adding titles)

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:30): that seems about as good a reason for warning as it would be to warn on onclick because you can't have more than one handler set that way, and additional ones get slightly different behavior (scope chain, etc)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:31): i.e. not completely bogus, but if it were a compiler I'd probably turn that warning off

65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:33): and if we're talking mandatory vs. optional diagnostics, then it might be better to leave it up to individual validators to decide what warnings they emit in addition to errors, and compete on usefulness and quality of those
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:33): much as C compilers all give basically the same syntax errors, but compete on usefulness of optional warnings
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:34): yeah
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:34): maybe
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:34): (I suspect gcc has far more useful warnings than it would if they were all defined by the C standard)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:34): it wouldn't hurt for the spec to editorially suggest some things as possible optional diagnostics
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:35): I should get going
69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (07:35): ttyl
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:35): (btw some people might find a warning on use of inline event handler attributes actually useful)
65325d50b2e25aca54bc871b89758c9c (07:35): (since it's not uncommon to ban them as a house style for a particular site)

69b0d3dfe919a6b860a9fac82de52a7e (08:38): to answer your question, the UA is always allowed to be helpful
